        • 3. Write/override methods that implement maze specific problem environment
        • 4. Call search module interface methods

search module
  • API Reference
  • View page source

API ReferenceÔÉÅ

This module provides a framework for solving path finding problems using common search algorithms like Breadth-First Search (BFS) and Depth-First Search (DFS).

It presents two interface classes: ‚ÄòSearchProblem‚Äô and ‚ÄòNode‚Äô. Both are abstract classes. You must subclass each one. Create your own two derived classes where you will write code to implement the following methods, specific for your problem:

SearchProblem.__init__() Node.actions() Node.result()

You may also want to override the following methods, if necessary for your problem:

Node.__init__() Node.__repr__()

To achieve a solution representation adapted to your specific problem, you may also want to override this methods:

SearchProblem.show_solution() SearchProblem.save_algorithm_steps_to_file()

Once base classes have been implemented, you just call SearchProblem interface methods:

solve() show_solution() save_algorithm_steps_to_file()

class search.SearchProblem[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: ABC

Represents an abstract search problem.

It defines the common methods and properties needed for implementing search algorithms.

Derived classes need to override the __init__() method to include problem-specific attributes. show_solution() and save_algorithm_steps_to_file() methods are usual candidates for override.

start_nodeÔÉÅ

The initial state of the search problem.

Type:

Optional[Node]

goal_nodeÔÉÅ

The goal state of the search problem.

Type:

Optional[Node]

algorithmÔÉÅ

The search algorithm to use (e.g., ‚ÄòBFS‚Äô, ‚ÄòDFS‚Äô).

Type:

Optional[str]

frontierÔÉÅ

The frontier used in the search algorithm.

Type:

_Frontier

explored_nodesÔÉÅ

The set of nodes that have been explored.

Type:

_ExploredNodes

solutionÔÉÅ

The solution path from the start node to the goal node.

Type:

_Solution

algorithm_logÔÉÅ

A handler for recording algorithm execution steps.

Type:

_LogHandler

__init__()[source]ÔÉÅ

Initializes the SearchProblem object.

This method sets up the ‚Äòstart_node‚Äô and ‚Äògoal_node‚Äô attributes, both initially assigned as None. It also initializes other attributes (e.g., frontier, explored nodes, solution) by calling _initialize_search_components().

Note

This method MUST be overridden. Redefined method in subclass:

  • MUST assign ‚Äòstart_node‚Äô and ‚Äògoal_node‚Äô attributes with appropriate values.

  • MUST call super().__init__() (generally as first statement)

  • MAY define other attributes relevant to the specific search problem, if needed by actions() or result() methods in ‚ÄòNode‚Äô derived class.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

solve(search_algorithm='BFS')[source]ÔÉÅ

Solves the search problem using BFS or DFS algorithms.

This method initializes the search components (frontier, explored nodes, solution) and executes either Breadth-First Search (BFS) or Depth-First Search (DFS) to find a path from the initial state to the goal state.

Breadth-First Search (BFS) explores nodes level by level, whereas Depth-First Search (DFS) explores nodes as far as possible along each branch.

Maintains detailed algorithm execution log including frontier state, explored nodes, and node expansion sequence BEFORE each node expansion.

Parameters:

search_algorithm (str) ‚Äì The search strategy to use. Must be either ‚ÄòBFS‚Äô or ‚ÄòDFS‚Äô.

Returns:

True if a solution is found, False otherwise.

Return type:

bool

Raises:

ValueError ‚Äì If search_algorithm is not ‚ÄòBFS‚Äô or ‚ÄòDFS‚Äô.

show_solution()[source]ÔÉÅ

Prints the nodes sequence that form the solution path if one exists, along with the number of nodes explored.

The solution, if found, is printed from the start node, showing step-by-step nodes to the goal node, along with the number of nodes explored. If no solution exists, prints ‚ÄúNo Solution found!‚Äù.

Return type:

None

Returns:

None

Note

This method MAY be overridden to customize the output format.

save_algorithm_steps_to_file(log_filename)[source]ÔÉÅ

Saves algorithm steps to file.

Details algorithm name, number of explored and solution nodes, and for each algorithm step, the current state of explored nodes, frontier, extracted nodes, and expanded nodes. If no solution exists, prints ‚ÄúNo Solution found!‚Äù.

Returns:

None

Note

This method MAY be overridden to customize the output format or include additional information.

class search.Node(state=None, parent=None, action=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Bases: ABC

Represents a node in the search tree.

Derived classes need to override actions() and result() methods to include problem-specific logic. __init__() is likely to be overridden as well.

Parameters:

  • state (object | None)

  • parent (Node | None)

  • action (object | None)

stateÔÉÅ

The state represented by this node.

Type:

Optional[object]

parentÔÉÅ

The parent node from which this node was generated.

Type:

Optional[Node]

actionÔÉÅ

The action taken to reach this node from its parent.

Type:

Optional[object]

__init__(state=None, parent=None, action=None)[source]ÔÉÅ

Initialize a Node object in the search tree.

Parameters:

  • state (Optional[object]) ‚Äì The state represented by this node. Default is None.

  • parent (Optional[Node]) ‚Äì The parent node from which this node was generated. Default is None.

  • action (Optional[object]) ‚Äì The action that was taken to reach this node from its parent. Default is None.

Returns:

None

Return type:

None

Note

This method MAY be overridden. Redefined method in subclass:

  • MUST call super().__init__() (generally as first statement)

  • MAY define other attributes relevant to the specific search problem, if needed by actions() or result() methods

abstract actions(search_problem)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return a list of valid actions for this node.

Note

This method MUST be implemented in a subclass.

Parameters:

search_problem (SearchProblem) ‚Äì The problem being solved, which provides the context and constraints for determining valid actions.

Returns:

A list of actions available from this node. If no actions are available, an empty list should be returned.

Example: If your search problem is to find a path in a maze, this method should return all valid moves (e.g., ‚Äòup‚Äô, ‚Äòdown‚Äô, ‚Äòleft‚Äô, ‚Äòright‚Äô) that can be taken from the current state.

Return type:

list

Raises:

NotImplementedError ‚Äì If the method is not implemented by a subclass.

abstract result(action, search_problem)[source]ÔÉÅ

Return the resulting node from performing the given action.

Note

This method MUST be implemented in a subclass.

Parameters:

  • action (object) ‚Äì The action to be performed.

  • search_problem (SearchProblem) ‚Äì The problem being solved.

Returns:

The resulting node after ‚Äòaction‚Äô is performed.

Example: returns node representing new position in a maze after a movement (‚Äòaction‚Äô) provided by ‚Äòactions()‚Äô

Return type:

Node

node_action()[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns the action that was taken to reach this node from its parent.

Returns:

The action that was taken to reach this node.

Return type:

Optional[object]

node_state()[source]ÔÉÅ

Returns the state represented by this node.

Returns:

The state represented by this node.

Return type:

Optional[object]

expand(search_problem)[source]ÔÉÅ

Expands the current node by generating all possible child nodes.

This method uses the node‚Äôs actions() method to get valid actions and result() method to generate child nodes for each action.

Parameters:

search_problem (SearchProblem) ‚Äì The search problem instance providing the context for expanding this node.

Returns:

A list of child Node objects resulting from applying all

valid actions to the current node.

Return type:

list
